clues.text: The collection of laws abbreviated U.S.C. is the United States this
To lawmen "perp" is short for this person
This old British court of Common Law was abbreviated Q.B. or K.B., depending
This official is the head of the United States D.O.J.
It's the H.L.R. first published in 1887
A little lie of this color is not intended to cause any harm
To deceive someone is to "pull" this material "over the eyes"
To bluff, not just at cards, wear this "face"
The title of Spike Lee's 2000 joint, it means cheated by trickery
An offstage area where prompters whispered lines to actors gave us this phrase for impromptu performing

rounds.category: HAPPY BIRTHDAY, THE NEW YORK TIMES
rounds.comments: (Alex: 150 years ago today The New York Times began publishing its newspaper, and so we want to wish them a happy birthday: a whole category devoted to them.)

clues.text: This was the price of Volume I, No. 1 on Sept. 18, 1851; subscribers probably wanted a discount anyway
In 1904, the paper moved to this area now named for it & later cleaned up by Disney & Rudy
2-word name for the section with headlines about "Clues to the Cosmos" & "Plants as Pollution Sponges"
The Times' 1946 coverage of its first session added an "O" to the initials familar today
This New York Times editor married to Margaret Truman had a biblical last name
One of the 2 films for which Barbra Streisand has won an Oscar
This 2000 love story that won 4 Oscars is the highest-grossing foreign language film in North America
In 1973, "The Godfather" won Best Picture, while this musical won 8 Oscars
Followed by several sequels, this 1970 film was the first modern disaster movie nominated for Best Picture
This 3-time Oscar winner won his third Academy Award for playing Judge Roy Bean in "The Westerner"
The EPA tells yard owners that using a push instead of a power type of this can save 80 pounds of emissions a year
In the 1870s Mary Potts filled a "pressing" need by putting a handle on this object
Common term for a hanging grid that kills bugs by electrocution
Images on the PC are at your "finger"tips with these, like Sony's Mavica & Nikon's Coolpix
A crumb-collecting box with a hinged lid is called the "silent" type of this servant
This island has less than 1 person per square mile; Godthaab, its largest city, has fewer than 15,000 people
Surrounded by 2 populous countries, Russia & China, it only has 4 people per square mile
Althings considered, this North Atlantic country has 7 people per square mile
The people are spread pretty thin in this country that was formerly Dutch Guiana
The Tswana make up about half the sparse population of this African country
This term for baby frogs means "round head", so their enemies must be Cavaliers
If you were a Hun in 450 A.D. this man was your king
To sing "the home of the brave" in the home of the National League Braves, you have to be in this stadium
In the Marvel Comics universe it's Tony Stark's alter ego
His libretto for the opera "The Devil and Daniel Webster" was based on his own short story
A marriage-minded monster awaits this title creation in a 1935 horror classic starring Elsa Lanchester
A dimwitted shut-in becomes the toast of Washington, D.C. society in this comedy starring Peter Sellers
As Josef Mengele, Gregory Peck sets out to breed a new race of Hitlers in this thriller
Bogie stars as Philip Marlowe in this 1946 film noir classic based on Raymond Chandler's first novel
Stanley Kubrick's directorial style in this 1975 movie mimicked the detached manner of 18th century English painters
In 1964 he introduced his first musical synthesizer; it was used on Walter Carlos' "Switched On Bach" LP
In 1854, he demonstrated his elevator safety device by ascending in an elevator & having the rope cut
In 1922, he marketed quick-frozen fish, his first packaged frozen food product
There was little demand for his revolver until the Mexican-American War when the U.S. government ordered 1,000
In 1769, he obtained his first patent, a separate condensing chamber & other improvements to the steam engine
Returning from the Third Crusade, this English "lion" king was kidnapped & held until a huge ransom was paid in 1194
Assassin James Earl Ray was arrested in this capital city June 8, 1968 by Scotland Yard detectives
This publishing heiress was kidnapped on February 4, 1974
Bank robber Clyde Barrow died along with this woman in a 1930s police ambush
The man who shot Alexander Hamilton in a duel was vice president under this man
"Hi, cher" isn't necessarily a pop star greeting; "cher" means this endearing term
You'll find a "cocodril" on the bayou but it isn't a crocodile; it's this relative
Who was that masked animal?  It was a chaoui, or this creature with 5 or 6 dark rings on its tail
Kawasaki knows "laissez les bons temps rouler!" means this
"May a pregnant yak chew on your ears for eternity" is a bad example of what Cajuns call gris gris or this

rounds.category: THEATRE IN THE NEW YORK TIMES
rounds.comments: (Alex: The New York Times is celebrating its 150th birthday this week.)

clues.text: The Times thinks it's fitting that the musical revue "newyorkers" features this statue singing a torch song
According to the Times, this show is "Ireland's answer to the Rockettes"
Reba McEntire said that this musical show she joined in 2001 felt like her life story because she's so similar to Annie Oakley
Ben Brantley said the Jetsons-style Egyptian outfits in this opera-inspired show "should top every drag queen's must-have list"
Maxmillan Schell talked to the Times about his new role in the 2001 stage version of this film that won him an Oscar

rounds.text: The brilliance of Anne Brown, a soprano, changed the title of a 1935 opera that was to be called simply this one name
